awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Access Expansion: Growing a Network of Equity-Focused Programs in the Physical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Access Network, a project aimed at substantially improving equity and inclusion in the physical sciences. Research has shown that many common existing cultural features of physics departments disproportionately and negatively impact women and underrepresented minority students, ultimately leading to their attrition. Students and faculty in physics departments have created programs using research-based strategies that cultivate a culture that welcomes and values students’ different identities.  The Access Network, formed in 2015, combines nine of these single campus programs into a national network while providing them with resources, expertise, and knowledge related to equity work, institutional change, and STEM education. Evidence shows that Access sites have positively transformed the student experience, and that the Network supports the success of these sites. The lessons learned in developing intensive mentorship and workshops to new sites and deliberately expanding leadership will be of value to others attempting to apply best practices in student support to new populations and scale local efforts to national movements. Documentation will expand the set of resources for new and existing programs, which can be used within the Network and beyond. Finally, ongoing evaluation will contribute to an understanding of the impacts of the Network on the individual sites and of the sites on their participants.

The Access Network works towards a more equitable and inclusive physics culture. Driven by a set of shared principles (e.g., student voice, community building) and a suite of programmatic offerings (e.g., mentorship, model building courses, community events, early research opportunities), each site is tailored to the needs of its unique population, ranging from a large number of Deaf and hard of hearing students at the Rochester Institute of Technology to Black commuter students at Chicago State University. The Network supports each site by providing relevant expertise, community support, mentored leadership opportunities, and shared resources.  By helping students succeed and empowering them as leaders, Access supports these students in changing the culture of physics to make it more inclusive, welcoming, and equitable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
What is The Access Network? The Access Network (https://accessnetwork.org/) is an organization of university students, staff, and faculty members striving to create a diverse and equitable academic STEM community. The Network connects nine student-led, equity-oriented, university-based programs (called "sites"). The goals of Access are to model a STEM community that values equity, student leadership, and holistic support, as well as to provide shared resources for social justice work in STEM education. Each Access site offers a set of support programs fine-tuned to their local context including personal support (e.g., mentoring and scholarships), authentic scientific experiences (e.g., early start summer programs, academic year courses, and early research experiences), and student empowerment and community (e.g., student leadership roles, diversity workshops, and social activities), all of which support the sustained success of students from minoritized backgrounds in STEM by building community, sense of belonging, and positive science identities.

At Access, we: (a) recognize students' expertise, (b) are committed to advancing equity and inclusion, (c) share power, (d) share resources, (e) care for each other, and (f) aim for improvement, individually and collectively. Access acknowledges that we must learn from marginalized people how to do equity and inclusion work well, and therefore create structures to support one another's learning. We engage in intentional, authentic collaboration with students in efforts to support their communities, which includes adapting resources, aligning programs, and changing Access itself to better fit their local sites' needs.

What has our organization accomplished in this three year period? The Access Network successfully held 3 Network-wide, in-person Assemblies. These events brought together 38 people in 2022, 43 people in 2023, and 47 people in 2024, cumulatively reaching 90 unique participants. This grant supported 27 Assembly fellowships to students who were responsible for supporting the collaborative designing, planning, and running of Assembly sessions (reaching 26 unique students). At our Assemblies, student leaders expanded their toolkit for reflecting, organizing, and acting locally to address issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM. Many past attendees have appreciated meeting like-minded people that are committed to tackling these issues and have found engaging with the Access community to relieve the strain of isolation that some students experience in STEM departments.

This grant also supported 54 Network communication fellowships to students who were responsible for facilitating communication between local sites and Network leaders, representing their site in Network decision-making, and collaborating on projects (reaching 38 unique students). 

In this grant, we expanded our Network's capacity by developing new organizational processes, adding people to our central leadership team of Core Organizers (COs), and developing new capacities in our leaders. We onboarded 15 new COs, re-instilling student representation within our central leadership team. Lastly, we expanded COs' capacities for contributing to various Network activities. For example, 4 COs newly took on mentorship of Network Fellows, and 5 COs newly took on mentorship of Assembly Fellows (along with experienced COs).

We significantly advanced our dissemination activities through developing a mission, vision, and values statement; revamping our website; launching a social media presence; and completing a substantial revision of our guide to building strong near-peer mentoring programs. We also engaged in evaluation of our activities in collaboration with student leaders through formative feedback collected at Assemblies and internal studies. In this grant, we focused on understanding students' experiences in the Network Fellow role (Dalka, Shafer, Gutmann, & Turpen, 2023). 

What impact has the Assess Network had? 

Broader Impacts. 60 unique student leaders and 90 unique Assembly participants were directly impacted by the work of the Network and are now leaders of collectivist approaches to equity and inclusion work in the physical sciences. These leaders continue to grow in their prominence and influence. These student leaders are shaping the lives of students in their sites, and Access alumni continue to take Access innovations into professional settings. We see clear evidence of culture change within robust subcommunities in these STEM departments and workplaces.

Intellectual Merit. The Access Network has established itself as a national leader in supporting multi-institutional, student-led equity work in the physical sciences as demonstrated by its recognition across multiple national reports over the last decade. Our work on this project resulted in 1 PhD dissertation and one 1 peer-reviewed conference paper. This paper concluded that the Network Fellow (NF) team differs from other efforts to partner with students in that they are given a great amount of autonomy to define their projects and goals. This research found that students in the NF role gain experience with inclusive leadership and build capacity for change work. Recently, the Access Network was recognized as a partner organization in an institutional transformation grant proposal, due to its innovative propagation strategies for enabling institutional change. Lastly, Access members gave 9 presentations about the Network and/or sites at regional and national conferences.
